title: Leveraging Google Gemini for Data Analysis
text:
Workshop Overview
Duration: 4 hours
Goal: Learn to leverage Google Gemini‚Äôs free tier for data analysis in ecology and ornithology
What You‚Äôll Learn:

Fundamentals of AI and Large Language Models
How to use Google Gemini effectively
Practical data analysis techniques
Domain-specific applications for your research

Materials: All exercises are copy-paste ready for gemini.google.com - no coding required!

title: Leveraging Google Gemini for Data Analysis
text:
Workshop Schedule



Time
Topic




0:00-0:30
Introduction to AI & LLMs


0:30-1:15
Getting Started with Gemini


1:15-2:00
Prompt Engineering Basics


2:00-2:15
Break


2:15-3:15
Data Analysis with Gemini


3:15-4:00
Advanced Applications & Wrap-up

title: Leveraging Google Gemini for Data Analysis
text:
What is Artificial Intelligence?
Artificial Intelligence (AI): Computer systems that can perform tasks requiring human intelligence


Traditional Programming:

Explicit rules
Deterministic outputs
Limited to programmed scenarios


AI/Machine Learning:

Learns from data
Adapts to new situations
Pattern recognition

title: Leveraging Google Gemini for Data Analysis
text:
Machine Learning in Ecology
Applications You Might Know:

Species identification from images (iNaturalist)
Audio classification for bird calls (Merlin)
Habitat modeling from satellite imagery
Climate prediction models

These all use different types of machine learning!

title: Leveraging Google Gemini for Data Analysis
text:
What are Large Language Models?
Large Language Models (LLMs): AI systems trained on vast amounts of text data
Key Characteristics:

Understand and generate human-like text
Can reason about complex topics
Trained on billions of parameters
General-purpose (not just one task)

Examples: GPT-4, Claude, Google Gemini, Llama

title: Leveraging Google Gemini for Data Analysis
text:
How Do LLMs Work?
Simplified Process:

Training: Read millions of documents (books, websites, papers)
Pattern Learning: Identify relationships between words and concepts
Prediction: Generate text by predicting what comes next
Fine-tuning: Improve through feedback and instruction

Think of it as: A very sophisticated autocomplete that understands context

title: Leveraging Google Gemini for Data Analysis
text:
Introducing Google Gemini
Google‚Äôs Advanced AI Model


Capabilities:

Text generation & analysis
Code generation
Data interpretation
Multimodal (text, images, audio)
Long context understanding


Your Workspace Benefits:

Full Gemini access included
Enhanced rate limits
Multimodal capabilities
Enterprise security
Integrated with Google Workspace

title: Leveraging Google Gemini for Data Analysis
text:
Gemini Versions
Available in Google Workspace:

Gemini 1.5 Flash

Fast responses
Good for most tasks
Great for quick queries

Gemini 1.5 Pro

More capable
Better reasoning
Longer context (up to 1M tokens)
Best for complex analysis


For this workshop: You have access to both versions through your Workspace account!

title: Leveraging Google Gemini for Data Analysis
text:
Introducing NotebookLM
Google‚Äôs AI Research Assistant
What is NotebookLM?

AI-powered research and note-taking tool
Upload your own sources (papers, PDFs, notes)
Chat with your documents
Generate summaries and insights
Create study guides from your materials

Perfect for Research!

title: Leveraging Google Gemini for Data Analysis
text:
NotebookLM for Ecology Research
Use Cases:


Literature Review: - Upload multiple research papers - Ask cross-document questions - Generate summaries - Extract key findings
Data Documentation: - Upload field notes - Query your observations - Connect related findings

Collaboration: - Share notebooks with team - Centralized knowledge base - Track research progress
Writing Support: - Synthesize information - Generate outlines - Cite sources automatically

title: Leveraging Google Gemini for Data Analysis
text:
Gemini vs NotebookLM
When to Use Each:



Gemini
NotebookLM




General questions
Source-specific research


Quick analysis
Deep literature review


Code generation
Document analysis


Brainstorming
Citation management


Real-time queries
Long-term projects



Best Practice: Use both together for comprehensive research support!

title: Leveraging Google Gemini for Data Analysis
text:
Accessing Your Tools
You‚Äôre already set up!
Your Google Workspace account includes:

Gemini - gemini.google.com

Sign in with your Workspace account
Start chatting immediately

NotebookLM - notebooklm.google.com

Upload sources to get started
Create project-specific notebooks


Today‚Äôs Focus: We‚Äôll primarily use Gemini, with NotebookLM tips throughout

title: Leveraging Google Gemini for Data Analysis
text:
Understanding the Gemini Interface
Main Components:

Chat Input Box: Where you type your questions/prompts
Conversation History: Previous messages
New Chat Button: Start fresh conversations
Settings: Manage preferences
Activity: View past chats

Pro Tip: Use separate chats for different projects/topics

title: Leveraging Google Gemini for Data Analysis
text:
Your First Prompt
What is a Prompt?
A prompt is the text you provide to the AI to get a response.
Example Prompts:

‚ÄúWhat is ecological succession?‚Äù
‚ÄúExplain species-area relationships‚Äù
‚ÄúList common bird identification features‚Äù

Key Point: Clear questions get clear answers!

title: Leveraging Google Gemini for Data Analysis
section: üéØ Hands-On Task 1: Your First Gemini Interaction
text:
üéØ Hands-On Task 1: Your First Gemini Interaction
Exercise (5 minutes):

Open gemini.google.com
Copy and paste these prompts one at a time:

What is a keystone species? Give me an example from 
North American ecosystems.
Explain the difference between species richness and 
species evenness in simple terms.
What are the main challenges in studying bird migration 
patterns?
Notice: Response speed, detail level, accuracy
Share: What surprised you about the responses?

title: Leveraging Google Gemini for Data Analysis
section: What Gemini Can Do for You
text:
What Gemini Can Do for You
Research Support:

Literature summaries
Methodology suggestions
Statistical guidance
Code writing assistance

Data Analysis:

Data interpretation
Visualization suggestions
Statistical test recommendations

Writing Help:

Paper drafting
Grant writing
Report generation

title: Leveraging Google Gemini for Data Analysis
text:
What is Prompt Engineering?
Definition: The practice of designing effective prompts to get better AI responses
Why It Matters:

Same question, different phrasings = different results
Good prompts save time
Better prompts = more accurate answers
Essential skill for AI tools

title: Leveraging Google Gemini for Data Analysis
text:
Principles of Good Prompts
1. Be Specific
‚ùå ‚ÄúTell me about birds‚Äù ‚úÖ ‚ÄúExplain the migration patterns of Arctic Terns, including timing and routes‚Äù
2. Provide Context
‚ùå ‚ÄúAnalyze this data‚Äù ‚úÖ ‚ÄúAnalyze this bird census data from a temperate forest. The columns are: species, count, date, location‚Äù

title: Leveraging Google Gemini for Data Analysis
text:
Principles of Good Prompts (cont.)
3. Set Constraints
‚ùå ‚ÄúHow do I analyze diversity?‚Äù ‚úÖ ‚ÄúExplain Shannon diversity index in 3 paragraphs suitable for undergraduate ecology students‚Äù
4. Specify Format
‚ùå ‚ÄúCompare these species‚Äù ‚úÖ ‚ÄúCreate a comparison table of these three warbler species, comparing habitat, diet, and migration‚Äù

title: Leveraging Google Gemini for Data Analysis
text:
Advanced Prompt Techniques
Role Assignment:
‚ÄúYou are an expert ornithologist. Explain‚Ä¶‚Äù
Step-by-Step Requests:
‚ÄúWalk me through the steps to calculate‚Ä¶‚Äù
Examples in Prompts:
‚ÄúLike this example: [provide example], now do this with‚Ä¶‚Äù
Follow-up Refinement:
‚ÄúThat‚Äôs good, but make it more concise‚Äù

title: Leveraging Google Gemini for Data Analysis
text:
Common Prompt Mistakes
‚ùå Too Vague: ‚ÄúHelp with my research‚Äù ‚úÖ Better: ‚ÄúSuggest statistical methods for comparing bird abundance across 5 habitat types‚Äù
‚ùå Assuming Too Much: ‚ÄúUse the standard method‚Äù ‚úÖ Better: ‚ÄúUse Principal Component Analysis (PCA) to‚Ä¶‚Äù
‚ùå No Error Checking: Accepting first answer ‚úÖ Better: ‚ÄúVerify this answer: Is this the correct formula?‚Äù

title: Leveraging Google Gemini for Data Analysis
text:
üéØ Hands-On Task 2: Improve Your Prompts
Exercise (10 minutes):
Part A: First, copy this poor prompt into Gemini:
Tell me about bird diversity analysis
Part B: Now copy this improved version:
I'm an ornithologist studying songbird communities in 
temperate forests. Explain how to compare bird diversity 
between old-growth and secondary forests. Include which 
diversity metrics to use and why.
Part C: Create your own improved prompt for this vague question:
How do I analyze my data?
Your version should specify: data type, research question, sample size, and goal.
Bonus: Paste your improved prompts into Gemini and compare results!
Share: What made the difference in response quality?

title: Leveraging Google Gemini for Data Analysis
text:
Domain-Specific Prompting
For Ecology/Ornithology:
Always include:

Study system: ‚ÄúIn temperate forest ecosystems‚Ä¶‚Äù
Scale: ‚ÄúAt the landscape scale‚Ä¶‚Äù / ‚ÄúFor individual birds‚Ä¶‚Äù
Data type: ‚ÄúUsing point count data‚Ä¶‚Äù / ‚ÄúFrom GPS telemetry‚Ä¶‚Äù
Goal: ‚ÄúTo determine habitat preference‚Ä¶‚Äù / ‚ÄúTo model population trends‚Ä¶‚Äù

Example: ‚ÄúI have 5 years of point count data for breeding songbirds in oak-hickory forests. Suggest appropriate methods to analyze temporal trends in species richness.‚Äù

title: Leveraging Google Gemini for Data Analysis
text:
Gemini for Data Analysis
What Gemini Can Help With:

Understanding analysis methods
Generating analysis code (R, Python)
Interpreting results
Creating visualizations
Troubleshooting errors

What It Cannot Do:

Run code for you (free tier)*
Access your local files
Make subjective research decisions

*Advanced paid features may allow code execution

title: Leveraging Google Gemini for Data Analysis
text:
Workflow: Analysis with Gemini
Typical Process:

Plan: Ask Gemini for analysis strategy
Code: Request code for your analysis
Interpret: Paste results, ask for interpretation
Refine: Iterate based on feedback
Visualize: Get code for figures
Document: Generate result descriptions

Key: You‚Äôre still in control! Gemini is your assistant.

title: Leveraging Google Gemini for Data Analysis
text:
Example: Bird Diversity Analysis
Your Question:
‚ÄúI have bird survey data with columns: site_id, species, count, habitat_type. I want to compare species diversity between forest and grassland habitats. Suggest an analysis approach.‚Äù
Gemini Might Suggest:

Calculate diversity indices (Shannon, Simpson)
Test for differences (t-test or Mann-Whitney)
Visualize with boxplots
Consider sample size and rarefaction

title: Leveraging Google Gemini for Data Analysis
text:
Generating R Code
Your Prompt:
‚ÄúWrite R code to calculate Shannon diversity index for each site from a dataframe called ‚Äòbird_data‚Äô with columns: site_id, species, count. Then compare diversity between habitats using a t-test.‚Äù
Gemini Will Generate:
library(vegan)
library(dplyr)

# Calculate Shannon diversity by site
diversity_by_site <- bird_data %>%
  group_by(site_id) %>%
  summarize(shannon = diversity(count, index = "shannon"))

# Merge with habitat data...
# Perform t-test...

title: Leveraging Google Gemini for Data Analysis
text:
Generating Python Code
Your Prompt:
‚ÄúWrite Python code using pandas and scikit-bio to calculate Shannon diversity and create a boxplot comparing forest vs grassland sites.‚Äù
Gemini Will Generate:
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
from skbio.diversity import alpha_diversity
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Calculate diversity
# Create visualization
# etc.
Pro Tip: Always specify libraries you prefer!

title: Leveraging Google Gemini for Data Analysis
text:
Interpreting Results
You Can Ask:

‚ÄúWhat does a Shannon index of 2.3 mean?‚Äù
‚ÄúIs this p-value significant?‚Äù
‚ÄúWhy might I see this pattern?‚Äù
‚ÄúWhat are alternative explanations?‚Äù

Example Exchange:
You: ‚ÄúI got a p-value of 0.23 comparing diversity between habitats. What does this mean?‚Äù
Gemini: ‚ÄúA p-value of 0.23 means there‚Äôs no statistically significant difference (typically we use Œ±=0.05). This suggests‚Ä¶‚Äù

title: Leveraging Google Gemini for Data Analysis
text:
Working with Actual Data
Best Practices:

Don‚Äôt share sensitive data: Use fake/anonymized examples
Describe structure: Column names, data types
Show small samples: First few rows as example
Specify format: CSV, Excel, database, etc.

Example:
‚ÄúI have a CSV with these columns and first 3 rows:
species,count,site
RWBL,5,A1
AMRO,3,A1
NOCA,2,A2
‚Ä¶‚Äù

title: Leveraging Google Gemini for Data Analysis
text:
üéØ Hands-On Task 3: Analyze Sample Data
Exercise (15 minutes):
Copy this complete scenario into Gemini:
I have bird survey data from 10 sites. Here are the results:

Forest sites:
- Site F1: 12 species, 45 total birds, Shannon diversity = 2.21
- Site F2: 15 species, 52 total birds, Shannon diversity = 2.48
- Site F3: 14 species, 48 total birds, Shannon diversity = 2.35
- Site F4: 13 species, 50 total birds, Shannon diversity = 2.28
- Site F5: 16 species, 55 total birds, Shannon diversity = 2.52

Grassland sites:
- Site G1: 8 species, 38 total birds, Shannon diversity = 1.85
- Site G2: 10 species, 41 total birds, Shannon diversity = 1.98
- Site G3: 9 species, 39 total birds, Shannon diversity = 1.91
- Site G4: 11 species, 43 total birds, Shannon diversity = 2.05
- Site G5: 7 species, 35 total birds, Shannon diversity = 1.76

Questions:
1. Calculate the mean Shannon diversity for each habitat type
2. Does there appear to be a difference between habitats?
3. Would a t-test be appropriate here? Why or why not?
4. What would be the null and alternative hypotheses?
5. What biological factors might explain any differences?
Then try follow-up questions: - ‚ÄúWrite R code to perform this analysis‚Äù - ‚ÄúHow would I visualize these results?‚Äù - ‚ÄúWhat if the data isn‚Äôt normally distributed?‚Äù

title: Leveraging Google Gemini for Data Analysis
text:
Common Data Analysis Requests
Statistical Tests:

‚ÄúWhich test should I use for‚Ä¶‚Äù
‚ÄúExplain assumptions of ANOVA‚Äù
‚ÄúWrite code for a mixed effects model‚Äù

Visualization:

‚ÄúCreate a ggplot for‚Ä¶‚Äù
‚ÄúMake a matplotlib figure showing‚Ä¶‚Äù
‚ÄúSuggest effective visualizations for‚Ä¶‚Äù

Interpretation:

‚ÄúWhat does this coefficient mean?‚Äù
‚ÄúExplain this interaction effect‚Äù
‚ÄúIs this effect size meaningful?‚Äù

title: Leveraging Google Gemini for Data Analysis
text:
Species Identification Assistance
How Gemini Can Help:
Field Guides: ‚ÄúWhat are the key features to distinguish Hermit Thrush from Swainson‚Äôs Thrush?‚Äù
Diagnostic Keys: ‚ÄúCreate a dichotomous key for identifying local warblers‚Äù
Behavior Patterns: ‚ÄúDescribe typical foraging behavior of Downy vs Hairy Woodpeckers‚Äù
Note: Always verify with field guides and experts!

title: Leveraging Google Gemini for Data Analysis
text:
Literature Review Support
Effective Uses:
Summarizing Concepts: ‚ÄúSummarize the current understanding of island biogeography theory‚Äù
Finding Research Gaps: ‚ÄúWhat are understudied aspects of warbler migration?‚Äù
Explaining Methods: ‚ÄúExplain how capture-recapture methods work for population estimation‚Äù
Comparing Approaches: ‚ÄúCompare radio telemetry vs GPS tracking for bird movement studies‚Äù

title: Leveraging Google Gemini for Data Analysis
text:
Research Hypothesis Generation
Brainstorming with Gemini:
Your Prompt: ‚ÄúI study forest songbirds in fragmented habitats. Suggest 5 testable hypotheses about how fragment size affects species diversity.‚Äù
Gemini Might Suggest:

Larger fragments support higher species richness
Edge specialists dominate in smaller fragments
Migratory species show stronger area sensitivity than residents
Nesting success decreases with decreasing fragment size
Functional diversity declines faster than species richness

Your Role: Evaluate, refine, and test!

title: Leveraging Google Gemini for Data Analysis
text:
Experimental Design Help
What to Ask:

‚ÄúSuggest sampling design for‚Ä¶‚Äù
‚ÄúHow many replicates do I need for‚Ä¶‚Äù
‚ÄúWhat are potential confounding variables?‚Äù
‚ÄúCritique this experimental design: ‚Ä¶‚Äù

Example:
‚ÄúI want to test if bird feeders affect local bird diversity. Suggest an experimental design with proper controls.‚Äù

title: Leveraging Google Gemini for Data Analysis
text:
Writing Assistance
Paper Sections:
Methods: ‚ÄúWrite a methods paragraph describing point count surveys conducted at 30 sites, 3 times each, during breeding season‚Äù
Results: ‚ÄúDescribe these statistical results in clear prose: [paste results]‚Äù
Discussion: ‚ÄúSuggest possible explanations for why species richness decreased with urbanization intensity‚Äù
Important: Always personalize and verify! Don‚Äôt copy-paste directly.

title: Leveraging Google Gemini for Data Analysis
text:
Grant Writing Support
Useful Prompts:

‚ÄúOutline a research proposal for‚Ä¶‚Äù
‚ÄúWrite a broader impacts statement about‚Ä¶‚Äù
‚ÄúSuggest project timeline for a 3-year study on‚Ä¶‚Äù
‚ÄúList potential challenges and solutions for‚Ä¶‚Äù

Remember:

Grant reviewers may use AI too
Your voice and expertise must shine through
Verify all factual claims

title: Leveraging Google Gemini for Data Analysis
text:
Teaching and Outreach
Create Materials:

‚ÄúDesign a lesson plan about migration for middle schoolers‚Äù
‚ÄúCreate an analogy to explain ecological succession‚Äù
‚ÄúDraft text for an interpretive sign about local birds‚Äù

Citizen Science:

‚ÄúWrite instructions for volunteers collecting bird data‚Äù
‚ÄúCreate a FAQ about our bird monitoring project‚Äù

title: Leveraging Google Gemini for Data Analysis
text:
üéØ Hands-On Task 4: Domain-Specific Challenge
Choose ONE scenario (10 minutes) and copy it into Gemini:
Option A - Species Identification:
I observed a small songbird in a temperate forest with these 
characteristics:
- Size: smaller than a robin
- Upperparts: olive-brown
- Underparts: white with brown streaking
- Behavior: foraging on the ground, scratching in leaf litter
- Song: loud, clear "tea-CHER, tea-CHER, tea-CHER"

What species might this be? Provide a shortlist of possibilities 
and key distinguishing features. I'm in the northeastern US.
Option B - Research Design:
I want to study the effect of forest fragmentation on songbird 
nesting success. I have access to 20 forest fragments ranging 
from 5 to 100 hectares and one breeding season to collect data.

Help me design this study:
1. How should I allocate my effort?
2. What variables should I measure?
3. What are potential confounding factors?
4. What statistical approach would I use?
5. What are the main limitations?
Option C - Writing Help:
Help me write a methods paragraph. I conducted point count 
surveys at 30 sites (15 forest, 15 grassland). Each site was 
surveyed 3 times between May 15 and June 30, 2024. Each survey 
lasted 10 minutes. I recorded all birds seen or heard within 
50m radius between 6am-10am on days with no rain and wind <15 km/h.

Write this as a clear methods paragraph for a scientific paper.
Share: What was helpful? What would you need to verify or change?

title: Leveraging Google Gemini for Data Analysis
text:
Fact-Checking is Essential
Gemini Can Make Mistakes:

Hallucinations: Making up plausible-sounding but false information
Outdated Information: Training data has a cutoff date
Misunderstanding: Interpreting your prompt differently than intended

Always Verify:

Scientific facts against literature
Statistical methods with textbooks
Species information with field guides
Code by testing it!

title: Leveraging Google Gemini for Data Analysis
text:
Verification Strategies
Cross-Reference:

Check multiple sources
Consult peer-reviewed literature
Ask colleagues/experts

Critical Questions:

‚ÄúIs this consistent with what I know?‚Äù
‚ÄúCan I find a citation for this?‚Äù
‚ÄúDoes this code actually run?‚Äù

Use Gemini Itself:
‚ÄúIs this statement accurate: [paste claim]? Provide sources.‚Äù

title: Leveraging Google Gemini for Data Analysis
text:
Privacy and Data Security
DO NOT Share:

Unpublished data (especially if not yours)
Sensitive location data (endangered species)
Proprietary information
Personal information
Data with legal restrictions

Safe to Share:

Published data
Anonymized examples
Publicly available datasets
Generic/hypothetical scenarios

title: Leveraging Google Gemini for Data Analysis
text:
Ethical Considerations
Research Ethics:

Don‚Äôt let AI make scientific decisions for you
Maintain intellectual honesty
Acknowledge AI use when appropriate
Follow journal policies on AI

Data Interpretation:

You understand your system, AI doesn‚Äôt
Biology is complex; simple AI answers may be wrong
Statistical significance ‚â† biological significance

title: Leveraging Google Gemini for Data Analysis
text:
Limitations of Free Tier
Rate Limits:

Limited requests per minute/day
May slow down with heavy use
Resets after waiting period

Features:

No code execution in chat
Limited multimodal capabilities
Shorter maximum context

Workarounds:

Plan your questions
Use multiple sessions
Break complex tasks into steps

title: Leveraging Google Gemini for Data Analysis
text:
When NOT to Use Gemini
Don‚Äôt Use For:

Final decision-making without verification
Identifying endangered species locations
Analyzing sensitive/confidential data
Critical/time-sensitive clinical decisions
Replacing domain expertise

It‚Äôs a Tool, Not a Replacement:

Your expertise is irreplaceable
AI assists, you decide
Critical thinking still essential

title: Leveraging Google Gemini for Data Analysis
text:
Academic Integrity
Guidelines:
Acceptable: - Brainstorming ideas - Learning concepts - Debugging code - Improving writing clarity
Requires Disclosure: - Substantial text generation - Code generation (check journal policies) - Analysis suggestions used directly
Not Acceptable: - Fabricating data or results - Plagiarizing AI output as original - Bypassing learning in courses
Check your institution‚Äôs policies!

title: Leveraging Google Gemini for Data Analysis
text:
Multimodal Capabilities
Gemini Can Process:
Images: - ‚ÄúWhat species is in this photo?‚Äù - ‚ÄúDescribe the habitat in this image‚Äù - ‚ÄúRead this field data sheet‚Äù
Combinations: - Upload image + ask questions - Combine data tables with text - Analyze charts/graphs
Try it: Upload a bird photo and ask for ID help!

title: Leveraging Google Gemini for Data Analysis
text:
Using NotebookLM for Research
Practical Workflow Example:
Step 1: Create a Notebook for Your Project - Go to notebooklm.google.com - Create ‚ÄúSongbird Diversity Project‚Äù
Step 2: Upload Your Sources - Research papers on bird diversity - Your field notes (Google Docs) - Previous study results (PDFs) - Methodology references
Step 3: Ask Cross-Document Questions

title: Leveraging Google Gemini for Data Analysis
text:
NotebookLM Example Queries
Copy these into NotebookLM (after uploading sources):
Summarize the main findings about forest bird diversity 
across all uploaded papers. What are the common themes?
Based on my field notes and the literature, what factors 
might explain the patterns I'm seeing in my data?
Create a comparison table of the statistical methods used 
in these studies for analyzing bird diversity.
Generate a study guide covering the key concepts I need 
to understand for my analysis.

title: Leveraging Google Gemini for Data Analysis
text:
Combining Gemini and NotebookLM
Powerful Workflow:

NotebookLM: Deep dive into your literature

Upload 10-20 papers on your topic
Get comprehensive summaries
Identify knowledge gaps

Gemini: Apply insights to your work

‚ÄúBased on X theory, how should I analyze‚Ä¶‚Äù
Generate code for methods
Get real-time analysis help

NotebookLM: Document your findings

Add your results as new sources
Generate discussion points
Create draft sections

title: Leveraging Google Gemini for Data Analysis
text:
NotebookLM Features for Researchers
Key Capabilities:

Source Grounding: All answers cite specific sources
Audio Overviews: Generate podcast-style summaries
Note-Taking: Organize thoughts alongside sources
Timeline View: Track research progress
Shared Notebooks: Collaborate with team

Pro Tip: Create separate notebooks for different projects or research phases

title: Leveraging Google Gemini for Data Analysis
text:
Iterative Conversations
Build on Previous Responses:

Start broad: ‚ÄúExplain community assembly theory‚Äù
Get specific: ‚ÄúNow relate that to bird communities‚Äù
Apply it: ‚ÄúHow would I test this in my forest?‚Äù
Get technical: ‚ÄúShow me the R code for that analysis‚Äù

Advantage: Gemini remembers conversation context!

title: Leveraging Google Gemini for Data Analysis
text:
Creating Templates
Reusable Prompts:
Save effective prompts for common tasks:
Statistical Analysis Template: ‚ÄúI have data on [VARIABLE] from [STUDY_SYSTEM] with [SAMPLE_SIZE] samples. I want to test [HYPOTHESIS]. Suggest appropriate statistical approach and R code.‚Äù
Literature Summary Template: ‚ÄúSummarize current understanding of [TOPIC] in [FIELD], focusing on [ASPECT]. Include key studies and knowledge gaps.‚Äù

title: Leveraging Google Gemini for Data Analysis
text:
Integrating into Your Workflow
Daily Research Tasks:

Morning: Check Gemini for concept clarification
During analysis: Get code suggestions
Writing time: Draft/refine text
End of day: Plan tomorrow‚Äôs analyses

Project Phases:

Planning: Hypothesis generation, design advice
Data collection: Protocol refinement
Analysis: Statistical guidance, coding help
Writing: Drafting, editing assistance

title: Leveraging Google Gemini for Data Analysis
text:
Combining with Other Tools
Workflow Integration:
NotebookLM + Gemini: - Upload papers to NotebookLM ‚Üí Get summaries ‚Üí Use insights in Gemini for analysis
Gemini + R/Python: - Generate code ‚Üí Test in IDE ‚Üí Refine with Gemini
NotebookLM + Literature: - Upload papers to NotebookLM ‚Üí Ask cross-paper questions ‚Üí Generate literature review
Gemini + Collaboration: - Draft text ‚Üí Team review ‚Üí Refine with Gemini
NotebookLM + Field Work: - Upload field notes ‚Üí Query observations ‚Üí Track patterns over time
All Together: - Best when combined with textbooks, courses, experts, and traditional methods

title: Leveraging Google Gemini for Data Analysis
text:

New features regularly added

title: Leveraging Google Gemini for Data Analysis
section: üéØ Final Exercise: Plan Your Use Case
text:
üéØ Final Exercise: Plan Your Use Case
Individual Activity (5 minutes):
Think about your current research/work and write a detailed prompt in your notes or directly in Gemini:
Template to use:
[Describe your research context]

I want to [specific goal]

I have [data/resources available]

Help me:
1. [Question 1]
2. [Question 2]
3. [Question 3]
Example:
I study warbler populations in mixed hardwood forests. I want to 
determine if habitat quality (measured by tree species diversity) 
affects warbler species richness. I have 25 sites surveyed over 
2 years with bird counts and vegetation data.

Help me:
1. Design the statistical analysis
2. Identify potential confounding variables
3. Suggest appropriate visualizations
Optional: Test your prompt in Gemini and share results with the group!

title: Leveraging Google Gemini for Data Analysis
text:
Key Takeaways
‚úÖ AI is a powerful assistant, not a replacement for expertise
‚úÖ Good prompts = Better results (be specific, provide context)
‚úÖ Always verify AI outputs against trusted sources
‚úÖ Free tier is capable for most learning and research tasks
‚úÖ Ethical use matters - maintain integrity and privacy
‚úÖ Start small - Integrate gradually into workflow

title: Leveraging Google Gemini for Data Analysis
text:
Bonus: Quick Reference
Quick Prompts for Common Tasks:







Task
Prompt Template




Statistical Test
‚ÄúI have [DATA TYPE] measuring [VARIABLES] with [N] samples. Suggest appropriate statistical test.‚Äù


R Code
‚ÄúWrite R code using [PACKAGES] to [TASK] with data structure: [DESCRIPTION]‚Äù


Interpret Result
‚ÄúI got [RESULT] from [TEST]. Explain what this means for [HYPOTHESIS].‚Äù


Literature Help
‚ÄúSummarize current understanding of [TOPIC] in [FIELD], focusing on [ASPECT].‚Äù


Species ID
‚ÄúWhat distinguishes [SPECIES A] from [SPECIES B]? Focus on [FIELD MARKS/BEHAVIOR].‚Äù


Visualization
‚ÄúCreate [PLOT TYPE] in [R/Python] showing [RELATIONSHIP] with [AESTHETICS].‚Äù



Save these for quick reference!
